362 Other Conditions That May Be a Focus of Clinical Attention
Child Psychological Abuse
Child psychological abuse is nonaccidental verbal or symbolic acts
by a child’s parent or caregiver that result, or have reasonable poten-
tial to result, in significant psychological harm to the child. (Physical
and sexual abusive acts are not included in this category.) Examples
of psychological abuse of a child include berating, disparaging, or
humiliating the child; threatening the child; harming/abandoning—
or indicating that the alleged offender will harm/abandon—people
or things that the child cares about; confining the child (as by tying a
child’s arms or legs together or binding a child to furniture or another
object, or confining a child to a small enclosed area [e.g., a closet]);
egregious scapegoating of the child; coercing the child to inflict pain
on himself or herself; and disciplining the child excessively (i.e., at an
extremely high frequency or duration, even if not at a level of phys-
ical abuse) through physical or nonphysical means.
